title: A World Without Fossil Fuels Is Approaching. But You Might Not Live Long Enough to See It.
text:
Text size

Will the world ever be free of fossil fuels? That’s been a topic of much discussion in the runup to Climate Week, a United Nations-sponsored event that begins on Monday.

Renewable energy, such as solar and wind power, is now a bigger generator of U.S. electricity than coal, despite pushback against renewables from the Trump administration, which last week said it would end California’s ability to limit vehicle emissions. The Golden State’s rules, which encourage production of electric and hybrid cars, are stricter than federal regulations, which the White House wants to loosen.

What happens to oil still stirs the markets, as the recent attack on Saudi production facilities shows. Nonetheless, carbon-free investing’s clout is growing. Last week, 200 institutional investors, which oversee $6.5 trillion in assets, called on 47 big publicly traded corporations to align their lobbying with the goals of the Paris Agreement on climate, saying that “unabated climate change will negatively impact our clients, plan beneficiaries, and the value of our portfolios.”

A recent Deutsche Bank study of 1,600 companies in the MSCI World index showed that, over the past 20 years, the stocks of those releasing “positive” news about their climate footprint outpaced those of companies that didn’t. And over the past year, low-carbon-footprint exchange-traded funds have been hard at the heels of the surging U.S. market: While SPY has risen more than 21% this year, the iShares and SPDR exchange traded funds (tickers: CRBN, LOWC) based on the MSCI ACWI Low Carbon Target index are both up 19%-plus.

Fossil fuels won’t disappear tomorrow. The International Energy Agency doesn’t see world oil demand or production peaking before 2040. That doesn’t surprise Ian Simm, CEO of London-based Impax Asset Management (IPX.UK). Impax manages $18.5 billion in assets, including the Pax World sustainable mutual funds, and is well-known for its water and resource investing.

Simm notes that power generation, transportation, and heating each account for about a third of U.S. fossil-fuel use.

For power generation, says Simm, renewables’ costs have slid so sharply that “you could rationally say that by the 2030s, we could be fossil-fuel free.”

However, while transportation “technology is just about there, it will take until the 2040s…to get costs down,” so that electric vehicles are as cheap as internal-combustion cars, buses, and trucks. There’s also the legacy-asset issue; just about every American drives a gasoline-powered vehicle now, many of which will last another 10 or 20 years.

Heating poses the biggest challenge because “the cost of alternatives is very high. The two basic options are electricity and hydrogen,” Simm remarks. “Most electricity still comes from fossil fuels, and we’re struggling to replace them for non-heat electricity loads. Hydrogen either comes from electricity,” as ions are decomposed, or from methane reform, a chemical process that produces hydrogen from methane, using a catalyst. The latter produces lots of carbon dioxide. “It’s possible to capture and store CO2, but this is very expensive,” Simm says.

Upshot? A fossil fuel-free world might not materialize in your lifetime. Still, plenty of people—and companies—will be reducing their carbon footprints, creating investment opportunities, Simm says. He won’t name names, but the stocks held by the Pax Global Environmental Markets fund (PGINX) include Linde (LIN), Waste Management (WM), and Siemens (SIE.Germany).
